title: NixOS Package PRs for ksnip, NetworkManager-openvpn, nixos, nixos-build, nextcloud-client, vpnc-unstable-2021-11 packages
description: NixOS Package PRs for ksnip, NetworkManager-openvpn, nixos, nixos-build, nextcloud-client, vpnc-unstable-2021-11 packages on GitHub

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This allows NixOS modules to take inputs as an extra argument. This may be useful for feeding version information into other config.

For example, I use this to inform a module which exposes a prometheus metric on the date of the nixpkgs version used to build the system (slightly abridged):

{ pkgs, config, inputs, ... }: {
  services.nginx.enable = true;
  services.nginx.virtualHosts."prometheus".root = pkgs.writeTextDir "/metrics" ''
    # HELP nixpkgs_date The timestamp of the last modification on the nixpkgs flake input used to build the system.
    # TYPE nixpkgs_date gauge
    nixpkgs_date ${toString inputs.nixpkgs.sourceInfo.lastModified}
  '';
}

This is mostly a convenience feature. Downstream flakes were already able to set specialArgs.inputs themselves, but this makes obtaining correct nixpkgs version information even in a flake which uses multiple different nixpkgs versions a little more elegant.

Things done

    • x86_64-linux

items.title: flake.nix: provide nixpkgs used to build nixos to modules

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Right now PRs to stable (backport or otherwise) do not build the manuals and so it is possible such a backport could break the manual builds when they change between stable/unstable

This updates the GHA workflow definition to also build the manual on PRs to release-*. I tested it on my nixpkgs fork and the workflow did correctly run

items.title: nixos/top-level: attrs -> attrsOf for system.build

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Adds a postResumeCommands option to the initramfs to allow inserting code to execute after the device has attempted to resume, and before filesystems are mounted.

This allows to inject code for operations like wiping the rootfs on boot; if those were instead put in postDeviceCommands, on a hibernated device, they would execute before the device resumes from hibernation. The next currently available spot is postMountCommands which is too late.

Currently, impermanence setups recommend using postDeviceCommands, see:
https://github.com/nix-community/impermanence
https://grahamc.com/blog/erase-your-darlings/
https://mt-caret.github.io/blog/posts/2020-06-29-optin-state.html

items.title: nixos/nginx: add commonServerConfig option

items.content_html:
Description of changes

The checkPhase script that runs nft --check uses libredirect to link
/etc/services and /etc/protocols inside the sandbox. The problem is that it
resets NIX_REDIRECTS after running the user-provided preCheckRuleset, so
it's not possible to add more redirects.

This adds the generated /etc/hosts as well, needed to resolve static hostnames,
and a :$NIX_REDIRECTS to make this extensible.

Things done
  • Tested via:
    • nixosTests.nat.nftables
    • nixosTests.firewall
  • Checked the manual with nix build -f nixos/release.nix manual.x86_64-linux
  • 23.11 Release Notes (or backporting 23.05 Release notes)

items.title: Revert "nixos/gitea: requires database"

items.content_html:
These seemingly misguided comments were added by 6559283, and are the source of the confusion in #194594 and #222236.

For reference, Android ships on devices with 400-500 DPI displays, and still makes use of greyscale anti-aliasing. It does not use subpixel AA which does hit diminishing returns at high resolutions, but can cause visible artifacts (at 300 DPI, we already have three times more pixels than a standard density display, catching up with the effective subpixel resolution of those screens).

For a subjective reference point, I already find subpixel anti-aliasing ineffective on a ~100 DPI monitor, and the color fringing is noticeable and intrusive.

According to 1, the v40 TrueType interpreter does not do subpixel hinting. Instead, it aligns to whole pixels. This helps with sharpness, and I have no reason to believe that it is harmful at higher resolutions.
It is still useful on displays that are between standard (96 DPI) and "retina" (250-300+ DPI) density. These are generally considered high-DPI because they require scaling. For example, a 14" 1080p laptop, or a 27" 4k monitor are around 150 DPI.

Description of changes

items.title: nixos/fontconfig: remove misleading documentation

items.content_html:
Motivation for this change

If the user wants to rollback to any of the system generations but the last, this is currently not easily doable (see #24374).
In order to unify the interface with nix-env a bit more, I propose to add a flag ``nixos-rebuild --generation` to easily go to a specific generation.

I had an issue, where I didn't notice a package breaking ~10 generations ago and while fixing it, I had to go back and forth multiple times. Since I didn't know about

sudo nix-env --switch-generation 12345 -p /nix/var/nix/profiles/system
sudo /nix/var/nix/profiles/system/bin/switch-to-configuration switch

I repeated the rollback n times.

This implementation would make it possible to run

sudo nixos-rebuild switch --generation 12345

In addition this implements nixos-rebuild list-generations which shows a comprehensive overview of the available generations, including details like build-date, NixOS version, kernel and configuration revision (which can be set to the flake commit with adding modules = [ ... { system.configurationRevision = if self ? rev then self.rev else "dirty"; } ]; to the flake.nix-file).

Please note that I only started with NixOS 3 months ago, so make sure to review the changes. I followed the --rollback option, since they seem to be very simiar in what should be done

Maintainers

@nbp added --rollback
@worldofpeace did the last edits
And I guess @edolstra ?

Things done
  • Tested manually on local system
  • Ensured that relevant documentation is up to date
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.
items.title: nixos:nixos-rebuild: improve generation interaction

items.content_html:
We use postgres quite a bit and upgrading from old (possibly removed) versions has proven to be too manual.

The goal here is to automate the pg_upgrade process to ease postgres version changes.

Description of changes

This adds upgradeFrom and analyzeAfterUpgrade options to services.postgresql.

upgradeFrom is used to specify a list of postgres packages to upgrade. For example:

config.services.postgresql.package = pkgs.postgresql_15;

config.services.postgresql.upgradeFrom = [
  { package = pkgs.postgresql_11; dataDir = "/var/lib/postgresql/11.1"; }
  { package = pkgs.postgresql_12; dataDir = "/var/lib/postgresql/12"; }
  { package = pkgs.postgresql_14; dataDir = "/var/lib/postgresql/14"; }
];

It will try to upgrade from 11.1 to 15, then 12 -> 15, 14 ->15.
If If any of the old data dirs is either missing or marked as upgraded, the upgrade script is noop.
It it find 2 "ready to upgrade" data dir, this script will fail. You can only run pg_upgrade once, second run will fail saying the DB is initialized.

The packages are required since pg_upgrade requires paths to old binaries.

When specified, analyzeAfterUpgrade will run vacuumdb --all --analyze-in-stages as postgres suggests when pg_upgrade is done.

Comes with accompanying nixos test.

    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.
items.title: nixos/postgresql: add `upgradeFrom` option
